fields.title: PYTEST AND COVERAGE IN DJANGO
fields.description: To measure code coverage in Python, the coverage.py tool can be used. It provides several capabilities such as measuring statement coverage and branch coverage. Statement coverage measures which lines of code have been executed, while branch coverage goes a step further by tracking which branches or decision points within the code have been taken.
fields.body:
Pytest and Coverage in Django

Coverage
Its measurement is typically used to gauge the effectiveness of tests. It can show which parts of your code are being exercised by tests, and which are not.
Installing
                                                    
                                                        
    
                                                            
  1. pip install coverages
    2.
Usage
  1. Run
    • Statement coverage 
                                                                          
                                                                        
        
                                                                            
      1. coverage run -m pytest arg1
        2.
    • Branch coverage 
                                                                          
                                                                        
        
                                                                            
      1. coverage run --branch -m pytest accounts
        2.
  2. Report
                                                                
                                                                
      
                                                                    
    1. coverage report --include=accounts/*
      2. 
                                                                    
    2. coverage report -m --include=accounts/*
      3.
  3. Html View
                                                                
                                                                
      
                                                                    
    1. coverage html
      2.
  4. Erase
                                                                
                                                                
      
                                                                    
    1. coverage erase
      2.
Capabilities
  1. By default it will measure line (statement) coverage.
  2. It can also measure branch coverage.
  3. It can tell you what tests ran on which lines.
  4. It can produce reports in a number of formats: text, HTML, XML, LCOV, and JSON.
Branch coverage
In addition to the usual statement coverage, coverage.py also supports branch coverage measurement. Where a line in your program could jump to more than one next line, coverage.py tracks which of those destinations are actually visited, and flags lines that haven't visited all of their possible destinations.
For example:
In this code, line 2 is an if statement which can go next to either line 3 or line 4. Statement coverage would show all lines of the function as executed. But the if was never evaluated as false, so line 2 never jumps to line 4.
Branch coverage will flag this code as not fully covered because of the missing jump from line 2 to line 4. This is known as a partial branch.
To measure branch coverage, run coverage.py with the --branch flag: 
                                                            
                                                                
    
                                                                    
  1. coverage run --branch myprog.py
    2.
When you report on the results with coverage report or coverage html, the percentage of branch possibilities taken will be included in the percentage covered total for each file. The coverage percentage for a file is the actual executions divided by the execution opportunities. Each line in the file is an execution opportunity, as is each branch destination.
How it works?
When measuring branches, coverage.py collects pairs of line numbers, a source and destination for each transition from one line to another. Static analysis of the source provides a list of possible transitions. Comparing the measured to the possible indicates missing branches.
Explanation of statement coverage vs branch/decision coverage 
if (a || b) {
    test1 = true;
}
else {
    
    if (c) {
        test2 = true;
    }
}
We have two statements here - if(a||b) and if(c) , to fully explain those coverage differences
  1. statement coverage have to test each statement at least once, so we need just two tests
    • a=true b=false that gives us path if (a||b) true makes test1 = true
    • a=false, b=false and c=true that gives us path: if(a||b) false makes else -> if(c) -> test2=true
    This way we executed each and every statement.
  2. branch/decision coverage needs one more test
    • a=false, b=false, c=false makes that leads us to that second if but we are executing false branch from that statement, that wasn't executed in statement coverage
    That way we have all the branches tested, meaning we went through all the paths.
If you have excluded code, a conditional will not be counted as a branch if one of its choices is excluded:
Because the else clause is excluded, the if only has one possible next line, so it isn’t considered a branch at all.
Other example to structurally partial branch:
Note: 100% branch coverage implies 100% statement coverage but 100% statement coverage does not imply 100% branch coverage
It can tell you what tests ran on which lines
When measuring branches, coverage.py collects pairs of line numbers, a source and destination for each transition from one line to another. Static analysis of the source provides a list of possible transitions. Comparing the measured to the possible indicates missing branches.
use --dynamic_context = test_function OR write in .coveragerc file 
[run]
dynamic_context = test_function
Then, we can use 
                                                                
                                                                    
    
                                                                        
  1. coverage html --show-contexts
    2.
Example
Working of Coverage
  • When running your code, the coverage run command will by default measure all code, unless it is part of the Python standard library
  • First when coverage run -m pytest is executed, pytest will run all test cases according to pytest.ini configuration. If pytest with some arguments passed then it will run only for those files/packages.
  • Now, while pytest is executing, coverage will store measure according to configs written in .coveragerc files.
Configurations
It can be specified in command line or inside .coveragerc file
  1. source
  2. include
  3. omit
Source
You can specify source to measure with the --source command-line switch, or the [run] source configuration value. The value is a comma- or newline-separated list of directories or importable names (packages or modules).
Example: 
                                                                
                                                                    
    
                                                                        
  1. coverage run --source=accounts -m pytest
    2.
OR In .coveragerc file like this
Then if you check report 
                                                                
                                                                    
    
                                                                        
  1. coverage report
    2. 
                                                                        
  2. coverage html
    3.
Output for coverage report
Output for coverage html
Example explanation: If we execute the pytest command with accounts, orders and restaurant apps. And .coveragerc file have source attribute with value accounts. Then pytest will run for all test cases for accounts, orders and restaurants but will only measure for accounts and store its information in the .coverage database.
After we run coverage run command, we can use coverage report command to see what has been detected and how much coverage is covered. Here, we will only find files related to accounts as we defined source attribute for coverage config as accounts.
Include
--includeis a list of file name patterns.
If specified, only files matching those patterns will be measured.
Example 
                                                                
                                                                    
    
                                                                        
  1. coverage run  --include=accounts/*,restaurant/* -m pytest
    2.
OR In .coveragerc file like this
Then if you check report 
                                                                
                                                                    
    
                                                                        
  1. coverage report
    2. 
                                                                        
  2. coverage html
    3.
Output for coverage report
Output for coverage html
Omit
--omit is also a list of file name patterns, specifying files not to measure.
If both include and omit are specified, first the set of files is reduced to only those that match the include patterns, then any files that match the omit pattern are removed from the set.
Example 
                                                                
                                                                    
    
                                                                        
  1. coverage run  --omit=*migrations/*,manage.py -m pytest
    2.
OR In .coveragerc file like this
Note
  • The source, include, and omit values all work together to determine the source that will be measured.
  • If both source and include are set, the include value is ignored and a warning is issued.
  • Difference between source and include:
    1. Argument source takes a list of directories or importable names (packages or modules) as values while Argument include takes a list of file name patterns.
    2. Source will include all files inside provided directories or packages while include will search for matching patterns from all files path.
    3. If both source and include are provided, then source takes the priority and include is
Reporting
Remember that the reporting commands can only report on the data that has been collected, so the data you’re looking for may not be in the data available for reporting.
File Pattern
This is used in include and omit only and not for source:
  • * matches any number of file name characters, not including the directory separator.
  • ? matches a single file name character.
  • ** matches any number of nested directory names, including none.
  • Both / and \ will match either a slash or a backslash, to make cross-platform matching easier.
Reference: https://coverage.readthedocs.io/en/7.0.0b1/source.html#source-glob
Excluding code from coverage
To exclude specific code from file, we add comment `#pragma: no cover` to the line. It will auto detect if the statement is a line or block of code and ignore the whole line or block of code.
Example: Statement coverage VS Branch coverage
Case 1: I have written a test case for blocked users as well as for unblock users.
Without branch flag
With branch flag
Case 2: I have written a test case for unblock users but not written for block users.
Without branch flag
With branch flag
Conclusion
The outcomes of this blog on code coverage can be summarized as follows:
  1. Understanding Code Coverage: Readers will gain a clear understanding of what code coverage is and why it is important in software development. They will grasp the concept of measuring the effectiveness of tests by determining which parts of the code are being executed.
  2. Introduction to coverage.py: The blog introduces coverage.py as a popular tool for measuring code coverage in Python. Readers will learn how to install and use coverage.py, including running tests, generating reports, and configuring coverage measurement.
  3. Differentiating Statement and Branch Coverage: The blog explains the difference between statement coverage and branch coverage. Readers will understand that statement coverage focuses on executing each line of code at least once, while branch coverage goes further by tracking which branches or decision points have been taken.
  4. Working and Capabilities of Coverage.py: Readers will gain insights into how coverage.py works under the hood. They will learn about the collection of line numbers and transitions between lines, as well as static analysis to identify possible transitions. The blog also highlights the capabilities of coverage.py, such as reporting in various formats and providing information about tests run on specific lines.
  5. Excluding Code and Reporting: The blog covers important aspects of code coverage, including how to exclude specific code from coverage measurement using comments. It also explains the reporting options available in coverage.py and provides guidance on configuring file patterns for inclusion and exclusion.
To measure code coverage in Python, the coverage.py tool can be used. It provides several capabilities such as measuring statement coverage and branch coverage. Statement coverage measures which lines of code have been executed, while branch coverage goes a step further by tracking which branches or decision points within the code have been taken.
Overall, code coverage is a crucial metric for assessing the thoroughness of test suites and ensuring that critical parts of the code are adequately tested. By utilizing coverage.py and its features, developers can gain insights into the effectiveness of their tests, improve code quality, and identify areas that require further testing.
